snippet: The dollar-driven drama “$upercapitalist” focuses on an uncannily prescient Asian-American hedge fund trader dispatched to Hong Kong to oversee a hostile takeover.
abstract: Jeannette Catsoulis reviews movie $upercapitalist, directed by Simon Yin and starring Derek Ting. Photo (M)9
lead_paragraph: Dry as new bank notes and doggedly uncinematic, Simon Yin's ''$upercapitalist'' approaches the seamy side of international finance with a story as stale as the subprime meltdown.The brainchild of the actor and producer Derek Ting (who wrote the script with Mr. Yin and countless others), this dollar-driven drama focuses on Conner (Mr. Ting), an uncannily prescient Asian-American hedge fund trader dispatched to Hong Kong to oversee a hostile takeover. Once there Conner is drilled in company etiquette and ''stealth wealth'' -- what to wear, what to drive and which women to demean -- by a vulgar boss (Michael Park) and a sleazy colleague (Darren E. Scott) whose talents appear limited to crotch grabbing and coke snorting. No surprise then that Conner soon finds debauchery a significant distraction from deal making.
